bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, September 1, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses Cuban attitudes towards Finlay and the identification of figures in the Cornwell painting.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, September 1, 1941
div1.p:
I am glad to hear that Finlay wrote you a second and more gracious
reply. His first letter was certainly inconsiderate. Regardless of his feelings
about his father's share in the glory he might have expressed some appreciation
that you gave him an obviously prominent place. As Recio and Albertini told me
more or less in confidence, they know the situation, appreciate the American
viewpoint and conclude “You never can satisfy some folks here,” meaning Finlay,
Dominguez and their school of thought. I appreciate your mentioning to Finley
my desire to see the “Cuban version” finished. It will help me in my unfinished
business in Cuba, and I do think it would be a fine thing, at least to finish up
the “preliminary oils.” For heaven's sake, preserve them. I may kidnap one
some day for my Cuban museum (if I ever get it).

You doubtless have by now Truby's last letter in which he strongly urged
that the figures for Cooke and Ames be switched. As I wrote you Mr. Cornwell
obviously made no real attempt to paint Cooke's likeness even though he had a
photo of him. Since Truby says the officer in white with the dark hair (my key--
figure #9, named by you as Cooke) could readily pass as Ames and the one in brown
(my key--figure #10) “looks more like Cooke” than figure "9, I would urge that you
simply tell Miss Vernon to switch the printed names for figures 9 and 10. No
need to change the numbers on your black and white photo unless you want to honor
Cooke by being mentioned ahead of Ames (which honor Cooke deserves).

Truby reminded me that Moran was actually a civilian clerk, not a soldier,
when he was inoculated. I, of course, knew that and am sure you did too. Moran
was an acting hospital steward (with the rank of sergeant) at the time of his
honorable discharge, July 2, 1900. He then became a civilian clerk in the office
of Gen. Fitzhugh Lee and was in that capacity when he volunteered to Reed. He re-
mained technically a civilian clerk till Feb. 1901, all through his experiences at
Camp Lazear and his recovery. But history has so universally spoken of him and
Kissinger as the first two soldiers to volunteer that it seemed more of an honor
to the army and more in keeping with Moran's social status (a “soldier” rather than
a civilian) among his comrades to represent him in your painting as a soldier, not
a clerk. Certainly Moran, when I showed him the original sketches, made no request
for absolute “calendar accuracy” in the matter and seemed to prefer tacitly to be
represented as a soldier.

Truby also tells me only the privates, and not the officers, wore the silver
crosses on their hats. Here again the “error” seems insignificant. Who the hell
cares! But it would probably only take a few cents worth of paint and a half hour
for Cornwell to paint out the crosses on the officers' hats sometime.

I assume the titles I gave the figures in my suggested key were accurate;
neither Kean nor Truby corrected them to me.

I hope you get to see Rankin enroute to Madison. I'll probably see you
in Madison; my reservation is The Loraine Hotel, Sept. 11-12.
I am trying to locate the Dix letters for you.

I note that you did not happen to include Agramonte's daughter to
receive an engraver's proof. I feel guilty to have two and for her not to
have any. Though I would like to keep both of mine why not let me return one
to you to send to Mrs. Rodriguez-Leon. You can later send me a framed autographed
regular reproduction. Although you have only had her criticism of the Cuban
version I'm sure she'd like the new one and she ought to have one. Let me
know. I've saved the packing they came in and can readily return it to you.
It should come from you, not from me.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
